title: Park Kyung-hoon
text:
Park Kyung-hoon (; born 19 January 1961) is a South Korean <a href="association%20football">football</a> manager and former player. Park played for the <a href="South%20Korea%20national%20football%20team">South Korean national team</a> in <a href="1986%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1986</a> and <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1990 FIFA World Cup</a>. He also won the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201986%20Asian%20Games">1986 Asian Games</a> with the national team. 
Club career.
Born in the slum of <a href="Seoul">Seoul</a>, (<a href="Suyu-dong">Suyu-dong</a>) Park had liked art originally, but he changed his career path to be a footballer due to his financial problem when becoming a high school student. He spent his professional career in <a href="Pohang%20Steelers">POSCO Atoms</a>, and won three titles in the <a href="K%20League">K League</a>. In the <a href="1988%20K%20League">1988 season</a>, he was named the <a href="K%20League%20MVP%20Award">Most Valuable Player</a>, but he thought that his teammate <a href="Lee%20Kee-keun">Lee Kee-keun</a> should deserve the award. He wanted to return it, but the K League Federation rejected his decision.
In 1993, Park announced his retirement and left for <a href="England">England</a> to study abroad. He also played for an English semi-professional club <a href="Yeading%20F.C.">Yeading</a> for a time, and became the first South Korean player to appear in the English <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>.
In 2013, K League Federation selected him as the right back of the <a href="K%20League%20Best%20XI%23K%20League%2030th%20Anniversary%20Legends%20Best%20XI%20%282013%29">30th Anniversary Best XI</a>.
Style of play.
Park is regarded as one of the greatest South Korean right back of all time. Nicknamed the "Progenitor of Overlapping" in South Korea, he was the first South Korean <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">full-back</a> to actively take part in attack.
